columns.title: Comfort zone
columns.content: Set an comfortable line length for reading and LESS the rest.

columns.title: Responsive and Readable
columns.content: This is a responsive grid but it's necessarily not fluid. Other grids can fill all the available space on a page, but that's not always going to produce a readable result.

columns.title: Narrative or navigation
columns.content: This grid is similar to using the CSS-3 columns module. It differs in it's brutal strictness to the grid. This is intended to improve scanning for narrative/navigation hybrids.

columns.title: Schmelements
columns.content: Nothing special about the elements you choose for the grid or it's items. Just add the classes and the grid will appear.

columns.title: For example
columns.quote: Nothing special about the elements you choose for the grid or it's items. Just add the classes and the grid will appear. Wait, I just said that.

columns.title: Couplets and Triplets
columns.content: The grid includes 2 classes for describing how columns are grouped. If you have a total of 2, 4, 8, or 16 columns, use grid--n2. If you have 3, 6, 9, or 18 columns, use grid--n3. You can use both also.

columns.title: Old explorers
columns.content: Below IE 9, the nth-child selectors and media queries will not work. The old explorers will find natural flows instead of floating columns.

columns.title: Spanners
columns.content: That tool doesn't fit this socket.

columns.title: Nor devices
columns.content: Making arbitrary choices based on device usage can be effective, but the goal here is to create a dynamic system the uses the line width constant to derive it's breakpoints.
